thread.title: Morgan's FG lifts Dawgs 9-6

author: Marc Weiszer
title: Morgan's FG lifts Dawgs 9-6
text:
By Marc Weiszer
ATHENS — Running backs Todd Gurley and Nick Chubb, who scored 72 touchdowns between them at Georgia, were on the sideline Saturday night when the Bulldogs couldn’t muster a single one.
No word if they were covering their eyes with the offensive display that went on in front of them because Missouri never found the end zone either.
Marshall Morgan’s 34-yard field goal with 1:44 to go split the uprights to give the Bulldogs their first lead of the game, and Georgia’s defense made the lead stand in a 9-6 victory in Sanford Stadium.
Yes, it was an ugly win, but the Bulldogs will certainly take it.
And so will the fans that remained to chant: “UGA! UGA! UGA!” before the Bulldogs ran the clock out.
Georgia (5-2, 3-2 SEC) avoided its first three-game losing streak since 2010. The Bulldogs were drubbed by Alabama in their last home game and then were dropped on Rocky Top by Tennessee after blowing a 21-point lead.
The first win for the Bulldogs over an FBS team in four weeks sets up a rivalry game on Oct. 31 in Jacksonville against No. 8 Florida with the SEC East race tightening. Florida lost to LSU 35-28 Saturday night for its first SEC loss.
Missouri (4-3, 1-3 SEC) seems about done in the SEC East after winning the division the last two seasons. The Tigers have losses to both Georgia and Florida now, two teams that are the top contenders in the division.
The teams traded field goals with Missouri leading 3-0 after the first quarter and 6-3 at halftime.
Georgia tied the game on a 24-yard Marshall Morgan field goal after the Bulldogs had first-and-goal at the 5 and kept the ball after an interception was overturned by replay.
The Bulldogs looked ready to go ahead but Morgan was wide left from 26 yards with 5:40 to play.
After freshman Terry Godwin’s 18-yard punt return with 4:18 to go, quarterback Greyson Lambert (23 of 32 for 178 yards, interception) hit Malcolm Mitchell for 8 yards on a third-and-7 and went to him again on the next play on a deep ball when Anthony Sherrillls was flagged for pass interference to give Georgia the ball at the 24-yard line.
Sony Michel (87 yards on 26 carries) went 8 yards up the middle and Morgan got a shot at redemption. This time he was down the middle.
Gurley is a rookie with the St. Louis Rams who returned for homecoming during an off weekend. Chubb will have surgery to repair torn ligaments in his left knee sustained a week earlier.
Without the player who was a Heisman Trophy candidate, Georgia leaned on is defense, playing for field position and slogged through the game offensively against a team that ranked 122nd in the nation in scoring and 121st in total offense. Missouri looked the part of having one of the best defenses in the SEC.
Georgia held Missouri to 164 total yards while gaining only 298.
The Bulldogs were fortunate when Lambert was picked off after a deflected pass on the first play from scrimmage and Ian Simon was tackled at the Georgia 1. The defense held, forcing a 20-yard Andrew Baggett field goal.
Georgia outgained Missouri 177-127 in the first half and controlled the ball 18:04 to 11:56, but the Bulldogs couldn’t convert a fourth-and-1 when Brendan Douglas was stopped for no gain (Michel was in the locker room briefly for an undisclosed apparent injury) and had an onsides kick from Morgan fail to travel 10 yards.
Georgia’s defense forced a three-and-out, but Missouri went ahead 6-3 after a 12-play, 84 yard drive.
Freshman quarterback Drew Lock (11 of 26 for 143 yards) completed five straight passes on the drive, including 24 yards to Russell Hansbrough, 14 to Ish Witter and 29 to Cam Hilton, but Georgia’s defense held after Missouri had a first-and-goal at the 9 and the Tigers settled for a 24-yard Baggett field goal.
“If we take care of business, we’ll get in the end zone,” Georgia coach Mark Richt said on a radio interview before heading ot the locker room at halftime.
It didn’t happen. Georgia survived what was called an interception initially at the Missouri 2, when replay showed that the ball hit the ground before safety Sherrills secured the ball.
On came Morgan who hit a 24-yard field goal with 33 seconds left in the third quarter.
Georgia lost one of its best defensive players in the third quarter when safety Dominick Sanders was called for targeting on an incomplete pass on the sideline to Emanuel Hall.
That removed him for the rest of the game and means he will miss the first half of Georgia’s next game against Florida.

Georgia 0 3 3 3 — 9
